2.rationale:
I'm looking at the board after my head reached (4,7). The remaining apples are at (8,4), (9,3), (2,0), (7,9), and (7,3). My head is at (4,7) and my possible moves now are:
• UP: goes to (4,8)
• RIGHT: goes to (5,7)
• LEFT: goes to (3,7) 
• DOWN: goes to (4,6) but that would run into my own body (from my previous move), so it’s not allowed.

Both moving UP or RIGHT get me closer toward (7,9), but moving RIGHT immediately gets me one step closer along the x‐axis. In upcoming turns I can then use UP moves to approach row 9. There are no blocks or enemy snake threats in that corridor, so it seems safe.

So my strategy is to steer toward the apple at (7,9). My next move, therefore, will be to move RIGHT.

2.rationale:
Looking at the board, my current head is at (5,7) while my target apple is at (7,9). To reach that apple, I need to increase my x‐coordinate by 2 and my y‐coordinate by 2. From (5,7) I have these legal moves:

• UP → (5,8) moves closer in y but does not improve the x position.
• RIGHT → (6,7) moves closer in x while keeping y the same.
• LEFT → (4,7) is invalid because that cell is part of my body.
• DOWN → (5,6) doesn’t help and would be moving away from the target.

Both UP and RIGHT bring me 3 Manhattan steps away from (7,9) (RIGHT: |7–6|+|9–7| = 1+2 = 3, UP: |7–5|+|9–8| = 2+1 = 3). However, by moving RIGHT, I immediately advance my x-coordinate, which aligns me better for my next upward move towards the apple. There are no obstacles—either my own body or enemy snakes—in that direction.

Thus, my strategy is to continue steering towards the apple at (7,9) by moving RIGHT now.

Next move: RIGHT.
